Be gone, pursuits so vain and light;</br>Knowledge, fruitless of delight;</br>Lean study, sire of sallow doubt,</br>I put thy musing taper out:</br>For what has love to do with you?</br>For, lo, I go where beauty fires,</br>To satisfy my soul's desires;</br>Where love and gentle beauty calls:</br>For me she had adorn'd the room,</br>For me has shed a rich perfume:</br>Has she not prepar'd the tea?</br>The kettle boils — she waits for me.

I come, not single, but along</br>Youthful sports, a jolly throng!</br>Thoughtless joke, and infant-wiles;</br>Harmless wit, and virgin-smiles;</br>Tender words, and kind intent;</br>Languish fond, and blandishment;</br>Yielding curtsey, whisper low;</br>Silken blush, with cheeks that glow;</br>Chaste desires, and wishes meet;</br>Thin-clad hope, a footman fleet;</br>Modesty, that turns aside,</br>And backward strives her form to hide;</br>Healthful mirth, still gay and young,</br>And meekness with a maiden's tongue;</br>Satire, by good-humour dress'd</br>In a many-colour'd vest:</br>Now come then boy of kind delight,</br>Attendant on the lover's night,</br>Fair his ivory shuttle flies</br>Thro' the bright threads of mingling dies,</br>As swift his rosy fingers move</br>To knit the silken cords of love;</br>And stop, who softly-stealing goes,</br>Occasion, high on her tiptoes,</br>Whom youth with watchful look espies,</br>To seize the forelock ere she flies,</br>Ere he her bald-pate shall survey,</br>And well-ply'd heels to run away.

But, anxious care, be far from hence;</br>Vain surmise, and alter'd sense;</br>Mishapen doubts, the woes they bring;</br>And jealousy, of fiercest sting;</br>Despair, that solitary stands,</br>And wrings a halter in his hands;</br>Flatt'ry false and hollow sound,</br>And dread, with eye still looking round;</br>Avarice, bending under pelf;</br>Conceit, still gazing on herself:</br>O love!  exclude high-crested pride,</br>Nymph of Amazonian stride:</br>Nor in these walls, like waiting maid,</br>Be curiosity survey'd,</br>That to the key-hole lays her ear,</br>List'ning at the door to hear;</br>Nor father Time, unless he's found</br>In triumph led by beauty's bound,</br>Forc'd to yield to vigour's stroke,</br>His blunted scythe and hour-glass broke.

But come, all ye who know to please;</br>Inviting glance, and downy ease;</br>The heart-born joy, the gentle care;</br>Soft-breath'd wish, and powers of prayer;</br>The single vow, that means no ill;</br>Believing quiet, submissive will;</br>Constancy of meekest mind,</br>That suffers long, and still is kind;</br>All ye who put our woes to flight;</br>All ye who minister delight;</br>Nods, and wreaths, and becks, and tips;</br>Meaning winks, and roguish trips;</br>Fond deceits, and kind surprises;</br>Sudden sinks, and sudden rises;</br>Laughs, and toys, and gamesome sights;</br>Jolly dance, and girds, and flights:</br>Then, to make me wholly blest,</br>Let me be there a welcome guest.</br>
